description: From Middle English noyse, noise, from Old French noise (“a dispute, wrangle, strife, noise”), of uncertain origin. According to some, from Latin nausia, nausea (“disgust, nausea”); according to others, from Latin noxia (“hurt, harm, damage, injury”); but neither explanation is satisfactory in regard to either form or sense.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Various sounds, usually unwanted or unpleasant.
examples: He knew that it was trash day, when the garbage collectors made all the noise.
The sudden noise made everyone jump.
She crept up behind him not making a noise.

entries.meaning: Sound or signal generated by random fluctuations.
(technology) Any part of a signal or data that reduces the clarity, precision, or quality of the desired output.
(figurative, by extension) Unwanted fuss or bustle; useless activity.
(genetics) The measured level of variation in gene expression among cells, regardless of source, within a supposedly identical population.

examples: The problems with the new computer system are causing a lot of noise at Head Office.

entries.meaning: (informal) Speech that is suggestive of an attitude or opinion.
examples: Despite encouraging noises made by politicians from time to time, the two sides there have never been further from an agreement.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Music, in general; a concert; also, a company of musicians; a band.
(music) A genre of rock music that uses static and other non-musical sounds, also influenced by art rock.

verbs.description: noise (third-person singular simple present noises, present participle noising, simple past and past participle noised)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make a noise; to sound.
(transitive) To spread news of; to spread as rumor or gossip.
